comments.commentBody: Probbsie - I think guys like Nick Lidstrom, Jarome Iginla and Daniel Alfredsson are all great leaders who represent the game very well, and among younger players, I'd put Jonathon Toews in that group.
I suggest the web site www.bogota-dc.co .... It gave me a lot of good ideas during my stay, don´t miss climbing la calera for a dinner!

Of course Fox and the conservatives want to use this episode to try and somehow punish NPR! NPR is the only news organization remaining that has no significant bias (at least not since Tomlinson, the conservative chairman of the CPB, resigned in 2005) and is dedicated to in depth news coverage. As we have seen recently, unbiased in-depth news coverage and facts are antithetical to the emerging conservative party, which relies on propaganda and ignorance to get people to hew to its ideology (take the issue of global warming or WMD in Iraq as perfect examples). Plus, the less competition Fox has, the better for its bottom line.

Look, what Mr Williams said may be how he genuinely felt, and he has every right to say it....but they didn't paint a very flattering picture of his feelings toward muslims (even if lots of Americans agree). And since he was an employee of NPR, his views reflect poorly on NPR as a whole (can we really trust what Mr Williams says now when he reports about muslims?), so they have every right to fire him. I don't necessarily agree with the decision, and maybe one could make the argument that we would rather have peoples' biases out in the open than closeted, at least then we know in what context to put their stories. But this is a very gray area, and there were clearly a lot of other issues at play in the decision: for example the NPR ombudsman has received numerous complaints about Mr Williams' appearances on Fox over the years, not just this one.

Finally, what would Mr Williams say if another journalist had made similar remarks about being scared to sit by a black man on a bus? What would people say if he had implied that all Christians were ignorant fanatics?

That is a very nasty story and it shouldn't be dropped.
First of all the firing of Juan Williams by NPR is beyond nasty it is unlawful because it breaks the First Amendment - Freedom of Speech.
Secondly the CEO of NPR insulted Williams publicly by suggesting that he needs or has a psychiatrist for expressing his opinion which doesn't agree with NPR's opinion.
Thirdly now finaly we the people can stop the funding of NPR with our tax money
that money can be used for better purposes than have a bunch of second rate liberals expressing their opinions, we can get all the opinions we desire for free
from the gazillion TV stations and radio stations.
And most importantly The Man Behind the Curtain, the odious George Sorros.
was publicly exposed. He paid millions to have Williams fired and mainly because Juan appears nightly on FOX. And not just Williams is the victim, Sorros is on the lookout for more victims. If not stopped he will continue his games.
Shame on us if we allowe this to go on.

So this is the great compassionate elite left?   The CEO of NPR should render her resignation and apologizes directly to Mr. Williams for her remarks.  Her remark about a Psychiatrist, was either calculated to hurt Mr. Williams reputation, or it was a poor attempt at a joke at the expense of a man she just fired, either way, it a show a person who is insensitive and mean.  This seem to be a running narrative at NPR, of people who are just seem mean.   This should not be allowed, if we want to have a civil socioty, that the left is alway preaching.   Here is a chance to put their words to action and do the right things, even if you think Mr. Williams is wrong, this was a direct attack on a person by a CEO.   She must go.

Williams is absolutely correct when he says that NPR has "no use for a diversity of opinion, ideas or a diversity of staff (I was the only black male on the air). This is evidence of one-party rule and one-sided thinking at NPR that leads to enforced ideology, speech and writing."  While NPR clearly had a right to fire Williams, their decision to do so is a clearly expression of liberal dogma, 'freedom of speech for me, but not for thee.'   It is also another example of the liberal reflex to twist their morals around to avoid saying anything offensive about Islam......but note the glee they take in making fun of fundamental Christians.

I would suggest a specially programmed Politically Correct Personal Computer (PCPC) be given to all future  NPR journalists in which they should first clear their commentaries. That way the public may be spared anything resembling real life from them. NPR: Moronic to the Nth degree.

I am a listener/supporter of NPR for over 30 years.  I have enjoyed Juan's reasonable, thoughtful commentary.   His firing is a gross over-reaction.  The only way I can register my complaint is by reducing my financial support for NPR.  Accordingly, I will only give half my usual amount this year.

Whether or not NPR has a certain bias, I think it is well within their rights to try to hold their news reporters to at least a semblance of impartiality. These folks are not hired as commentators, they are hired as reporters. We seem to have forgotten the difference in America. I admire NPR for at least trying to maintain that semblance of impartiality. If, as another reader wrote, NPR has not fired other reporters guilty of displaying partiality, then, certainly, the organization should be called on it and those reporters should be fired as well. But for goodness sake, doesn't anyone value attempts at impartiality any more?

I have been disturbed by Mr. Williams presence on Fox since he joined them. I have wondered how his association with an unfair and unbalanced wing of the Republican Party could continue to serve on public TV. Now we have the answer. One wonders why it took so long. Any person associated with Fox is unsuitable for public TV.
NPR thanks for saving me $20. I was going to pay but now forget it. No payment from me. Juan Williams was once reason I listened to NPR. Thanks for nothing.
"Golly gee, I just gotta admit, whenever I encounter a [black man/latino/woman with tatroos ...] I have to admit, I get worried, I feel nervous." Offensive? Out of line?

They never fired people like Dan Schorr, who clearly had an opinion on most of the stories on which he provided commentary.  I won't be sending any funding to NPR henceforth and I believe federal money should be withdrawn.  We have freedom of speech in this country.  Mr. Williams was probably in error to sign a contract that would have such strident restrictions as the one he had.  Of course, he will do much better on Fox's payroll.  Good luck to him.
NPR's always been bad.  Now they're useless.   We can only hope that sponsors start withdrawing sponsorship.

So this is the great compassionate elite left? The CEO of NPR should render her resignation and apologizes directly to Mr. Williams for her remarks. Her remark about a Psychiatrist, was either calculated to hurt Mr. Williams reputation, or it was a poor attempt at a joke at the expense of a man she just fired, either way, it a show a person who is insensitive and mean. This seem to be a running narrative at NPR, of people who are just seem mean. This should not be allowed, if we want to have a civil socioty, that the left is alway preaching. Here is a chance to put their words to action and do the right things, even if you think Mr. Williams is wrong, this was a direct attack on a person by a CEO. She must go.

While Juan is worried about "muslim garb" as non white person I am worried about another reality. It is fact that annually over 3,500 murders are committed in U.S.A ( in 9 years 31,500) and over 99 percent of these involve black men. Based on Juan's logic every time anyone in U.S comes across a black man it will be okay to call in police. On personal note every time I see a black man like Juan I should be feel terrified and start praying that I going to die.  Juan sold himself for few dollars. Cheers that NPR got rid of this trojan horse.

A few years ago Juan Williams came to the city where I live to promote a book he had just written. He was billed as an NPR commentator. Never mind the book or the talk he gave about it in one of the local churches. After the talk some of us lined up to meet him and speak to him. Earlier he had welcomed questions. When I finally got to his table - he was seated at a table and received his guests there - I asked him how he could allow himself to become a shill for Fox News. He looked me in the eye and told me that he was "the liberal on Fox." And that furthermore "it was good to have a at least one dissenting voice on the Murdock station." He was embarrassed (my impression) as he made his studied case for being an objective voice. What is now apparent is that it was all an act. I remember thinking how his rationalization seemed tailored and rehearsed. I think he has been conflicted for many years; now at least he can come clean. Put him down as just another prostitute for the hard right. Nothing more, nothing less. He talks a good game, but he has been found out to be what has always been - a right wing proselytizer. He belongs on Fox. It is his rightful home. Two mil for a soul! Not bad in today's impacted market.
I think that if everyone who has threated to stop contributing to NPR because of this firing were actually a contributor in the past, NPR would be wealthy enough to skip pledge weeks.

A few thoughts of a militant Centrist.
There are multiple ironies here, one of which is that Juan Williams has been a refreshing and valuable source of liberal opinion on Fox News. None of those opinions, of course, would be likely to get Williams in trouble at NPR--just as liberal opinions on matters of controversy have never gotten anyone at NPR in trouble. Another irony is that by propelling Williams into an expanded role at Fox it will probably increase his net income. Indeed, it would be greatly to Fox's credit if they gave Wlliams his own show. It would provide a much-needed counterpoint to Fox's conservative pundits and might even enlarge their already impressive audience.

Alternatively, of course, President Obama, might have everyone over to the White House for a beer and try to effect a reconciliation. If that worked, he could then take on the "Ground Zero Mosque Problem." It would have to be more fun than checking every day on the opinion polls for the November elections.
It's only up from here for Gibson.

Friscokid,

You say you are from San Francisco but clearly from Whine Country. Both teams have gotten breaks and made breaks for themselves.

Giants took two of three at home from the defending NL champs and have a chance to close it out with either Sanchez or Cain.

At the plate, the Giants are overachieving and Phillies are underachieving. We'd better hope it stays that way or it will be a disappointing weekend and winter.

Several Yankees fans commented that Teixeira's injury was a blessing in disguise to the Yankees in the playoff series because Teixeira had zero offense before he was injured. I agree with them, even though he had A+  defense and A offense in the regular season. But he could not hit in the first half of the season, in 2009 playoff, and again in 2010 playoff. Giraradi made the situation worse by keeping him in the 3rd spot which had hurt the team offensively. Berkman has been contributing to the Yankees offense in these two playoff series.

the home plate umpire blew the call...a foul ball by any other name is a foul ball...how can mlb still allow games to hinge on bad umpiring, he should be reprimanded and have to sit out the rest of the playoffs....phillies did'nt win, the umpire did....
also, Buck and McCarver and fox are insufferable! they did not even comment about it being a foul ball...
The definition of "nail biter".  Great baseball.
Felt like I was watching Little League. Not the best showing from either Giants or Phillies tonight. Miserable game until the end and even the weather agreed.
